Message.Title: What Shorts Know But Literally Can't Afford to Admit
Message.Msg: 1.) The doom and gloom has been substantially oversold. Even Jack Welch got it wrong and was unaware of significant improvements in the economy: The economy is improving more than professional forecasters anticipated, particularly in data on employment and housing, according to the Bloomberg Economic Surprise Index, which compares 38 indicators with analysts’ predictions. The index, based on gauges compiled by private businesses and trade groups in addition to government, confirms U.S. growth is generating jobs in the face of a global slowdown and looming federal spending cuts and tax increases known as the fiscal cliff." 2.) Wall Street hasn't just gotten the Intel story wrong, they have gone stark raving mad pricing in the same news again and again and again. Wall Street has priced in an $8 billion revenue miss. Intel's revenues would half to decline by half to justify the reduction in the stock price Wall Street has now baked in. Does anyone really think Intel's revenues will decline by half??? This is what happens when you price in the same thing over and over and over. Revenue miss announced. Chump Street prices it in. General economic conditions decline (which is why the revenue miss is announced along with the Windows 8 wait). Chump Street prices it in. Report of chip sales decline. Same thing and Chump Street prices it in. News of AMD having problems. Chump Street prices this in even though it's a good thing for Intel. And on and on and on. The same exact thing. 3.) Employment is improving. Housing has really improved. Consumer sentiment has reached pre-recession levels. The news from China is improving. 4.) Intel's mobility strategy is gaining strength. The new Motorola smartphone demonstrates this. Intel now has Motorola, Karbonn, MegaFon, Lenovo, ZTE, Orange and Lava selling its smartphones. And a big LTE roll-out in the US planned for 2013. 5.) Intel's new tablet design is really good and will open up the tablet market, especially in the enterprise area. 6.) Intel's fabrication lead is huge and growing every day. Intel is ramping up while ARM is coasting to a stop and will pause after 20nm for an extended period of time. 7.) Intel's WiFi chip development is going to give them a significant advantage with the Internet of Things (IoT) as connectivity of devices (modems, routers, sensors, RF Tags, ATMs, vending machines, signs, coffee makers, etc.) generates a new network as large as the existing cellular network with a revenue stream just as large. 8.) 2013 will be the year after which there will never ever be the need to buy an ARM chip except at the low end of the market as ARM evolves into the next AMD due to lack of technology, fabrication and manufacturing. 9.) Intel will have five 22nm facilities running in 2013 and quickly moving to 14nm. ARM is struggling just to provide 28nm to its customers. Those wanting state-of-the-art technology will have to move to Intel. 10.) Intel will continue its every eight quarter fab cycle. No company on earth can match it. It will continue its tick-tock strategy to integrate design and fabrication improvements. I believe Marsavian said it best: "Medfield is just the starter but Silvermont will be the main course and will ask questions of Arm chips that they probably won't be able to answer. Haswell is such an awesome design that will be like the second coming of Conroe which struck down Athlon64 with a mighty blow that AMD never recovered from. Haswell will be a similar quantum jump in performance and there will be sub 10W versions. 14nm Broadwall though will get the power down to 5W which is tablet class. At 14nm Intel is going to squeeze ARM from above with Broadwell and below with Airmont, probably only Apple's bespoke processor will still look any good in comparison. Even well before then the 32nm Medfield/Clovertrail generation will spread far and wide in phones and tablets and Windows 8 will give PCs a buying boost."

Topic.Title: Silvermont Details

Message.Msg: According to the latest benchmarks of the 2GHz version of Medfield vs the S4 from the Motorola Razr phones, Krait is at par with the current Atom core. If this is 25% faster per clock and the clock rate is also faster because of (32nm-- 22nm) Silvermont should be say 40% faster than Apple's current A6, A15 based ARM and Krait current gen (assuming that these three are comparable). Silvermont alternatives will probably catch up 2014 when TSMC 20nm comes into play. ---- The benchmarks in question: Motorola RAZR i Motorola Droid RAZR M ZTE Grand X IN Quadrant 4,226 4,944 2,710 Vellamo 1,928 2,442 1,550 SunSpider 0.9.1 (ms) 1,077 1,951 1,355 AnTuTu 6,175 6,364 N/A GLBenchmark Egypt Offscreen (fps) 41 56 N/A CF-Bench 3,115 9,392 873 SunSpider: lower scores are better As you can see, the RAZR i beats in one benchmark only. The 25% improvement in Silvermont, isn't clock, it's IPC, so if Silvermont had the same base clock (and turbo) as Medfield it would be 25% faster. If it has a faster clock, then the speed improvements would be compounded. If the 25% Silvermont IPC improvements are true, then she is going to struggle to gain any clear water against Krait especially with the various improvements coming with Krait in the next few months (faster clocks etc). As for the A15, it's IPC over the A9 is claimed to be 30-40%, with TI claiming an 50% improvement at the same clock over it's previous design (this is due to other things than just IPC). If this is true, and if the A15 can be clocked high without killing the battery then Silvermont actually falls behind the existing A9 to Medfield comparisons/benchmarks. If you want to have a feel of what 'better' benchmarks look like, head over to geekbench and search for various A9/Krait/Apple A6 then search on Atom. See where Atom win's and loses and by how much.

Message.Title: Redmond leaks Surface RT pricing
Message.Msg: [Well, it looks like we can officially declare the ARM Windows 8 offering from Microsoft to be dead on arrival. Microsoft really never did like ARM and was just going through the motions. Bump for Intel...] $499 sans Touch Cover Microsoft has inadvertently spilled the beans its upcoming Surface RT. The new tablet briefly appeared on the Microsoft Store and the listings more or less confirmed earlier pricing rumours, but they were yanked by Microsoft. The entry level version, with 32GB of storage and no Touch Cover keyboard ends up with a $499 price tag. An $599 will buy you a 64GB unit, or a 32GB unit bundled with the keyboard. So, the priciest model, with 64GB of storage and a bundled Touch Cover ends up at $699. Sold separately, the Touch Cover is priced at $119, while the black Surface Type Cover, with proper hardware keys, is priced at $129. This sounds a bit too steep and very close to what Asus is asking for its Transformer keyboards, which also feature a battery, USB and SD slot. So, the pricing is pretty much in line with entry level iPad versions, but we’re not sure that makes the Surface RT very competitive. The iPad boasts an unmatched ecosystem and a high-definition Retina screen, while the Surface features a 1366x768 screen and a completely new OS with a limited choice of apps. Let’s hope we're not looking at Microsoft’s next Zune. [Or Kin. Ed] From Fudzilla

Message.Msg: By Benjamin Pimentel 4%2%0%-2%10a11a12p1p2p3p INTC DJIA AAPL SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) Shares of Intel INTC +2.23% rose 2.4% on Tuesday, the best performer on the Dow Jones Industrial Average /quotes/zigman/627449 DJIA +0.82% , which was up 115 points. Williams Financial analyst Cody Acree told MarketWatch that the gains apparently were due to "more talk of Apple moving away from Samsung as a foundry" which has also led to speculation that either Intel or TSMC may be tapped to manufacture chips for Apple Inc. Relations between Apple and Samsung have been strained by legal battles over patents. Intel is set to report third-quarter results after Tuesday's closing bell.

Message.Title: Intel up 30% or more next year - VERY rational article
Message.Msg: Intel: Bears In Control But Bulls Could See 30% Next Year October 16, 2012 | 1 comment | about: INTC Disclosure: I am long INTC. (More...) Intel (INTC) reports earnings after the market close today and is expected to see a 23% decline in earnings per share to $0.50 versus $0.65 per share in the same quarter last year. The company has beaten expectations by an average of $0.04 in each of the last eight quarters but it is likely that the trailing earnings will be lowered to around $2.26 per share. While a continuation of poor PC sales may make the bears happy, the current price multiple is 30% below the near-term average and upcoming catalysts could improve sentiment. Problems mostly Cyclical The semiconductor industry is extremely cyclical and revenues can drop precipitously when business spending declines. Intel saw total revenue fall more than 9% from $14.2 billion in the third quarter 2011 to $12.9 billion in the first quarter of 2012 before rebounding in the last quarter. Expectations for the today's report are for a $300 million drop from the last quarter to $13.2 billion. The reason for the drop in revenues, and much of the negative sentiment as of late, is the slowdown in PC business. The switch from PCs to tablets and smartphones is driving an estimated 8% decline in revenues for the company's PC client group which accounted for $8.7 billion or 64% of total revenue in the second quarter. While the trend away from PC is something the company needs to address, much of the recent decline in sales is likely cyclical instead of a structural shift from the product. PC sales are expected to fall 1.2% this year, the first decline in 11 years. Is this really news though? Investors had to expect some bad news given the global economic picture and slower business spending leading up to the rollout of new Windows products. A Management Team that has Always Delivered Despite the weakness in macro issues, management has delivered with an operating margin of 30.8%, above 95% of competitors in the industry. Even with a 34% payout ratio and a 4.2% dividend yield, management has grown the book value of the firm by 7.5% annualized over the last ten years. A return on equity of 25.4% is great in just about any industry, but it beats 96% of Intel's competitors in the semiconductor group. The company had $13.6 billion of cash and short-term investments last quarter and cash flows from operations of $4.7 billion. Cash flow was more than enough to pay for $1.7 billion in investment and $2.2 billion in financing, including $1.4 billion for share buybacks. Even after recent weakness in shares, investors have been rewarded with a 7.1% annualized return over the last 10 years. Next Year Presents Strong Catalysts for Growth Windows has announced that it will only provide support for XP until April of 2014. While many businesses have already transitioned out of the system, next year should see an increase in desktop replacement. While Win8 failed to impress the markets when delivered on Nokia's (NOK) new smartphone, next year brings the launch of touch-enabled Ultrabooks at lower prices that could better utilize the new software. Further, the lower prices should help to bring in the late adopters into the product line. The company plans on launching Haswell in the first quarter. The new processor is expected to offer twice the graphics performance at significantly less power consumption than standard products. Beyond any micro-level events, any pick up in the macro environment will help to drive sales in developed markets as well as continue the strong growth seen in emerging markets. Even if trailing earnings come down to $2.26 and the trailing price-to-earnings ratio increases to 9.6 times, the stock will only have been cheaper 5% of the time over the last decade. While the stock saw much higher valuations before 2004, it has averaged 12.5 times since 2010. This average multiple is 30% higher than the current and upcoming catalysts could drive sentiment even higher. Weakness in PC sales may seem like a structural problem but the company has responded to industry changes before and has always been able to adapt. Next year provides several catalysts for a return of sentiment and a rebound to the average price multiple yields a 30% upside on top of a healthy 4% dividend.

Topic.Title: intc to buy amd soon my gut feel 3.50 buyout offer wish list

Message.Msg: In years past Intel purchasing AMD was unthinkable for anti-trust reasons. Intel had dominant control of the PC CPU business and acquiring the only other PC CPU competitor would not have been approved. Additionally, keeping AMD around lessened the involvement of the FTC and DOJ into Intel's business. However, the environment is different today. Windows runs on ARM processors and one can buy ARM servers, tablets and smartphones already. ARM supporters say ARM will be in every segment of Intel's business and the market has already priced-in damage to Intel's business future because of the ARM factor. In short, the big difference today is that customers have choice for their Windows and Android CPU's and an Intel takeover of AMD shouldn't be the concern it once was by anti-trust types. To Intel, there would be numerous benefits. First Intel would reclaim the x86 intellectual property the court unjustly gave to AMD in the '90s. Secondly, they would gain ATI's graphics technology and patents to gain further advantage over Nvidia and third, Intel would remove the constant pressure of having a perpetually weak AMD low-ball x86 pricing. What was unthinkable yesterday may well be possible today. Go for it!

Message.Title: Barron's reporting Apple dropping Samsung
Message.Msg: Apple is moving away from Samsung Electronics (005930KS), speculating that it has given a “major partnership” for its next chip design, the “A7,” to Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM), and that it is considering Intel (INTC), as well. What just happened? Apple is transitioning from ARM to INTEL. Why? Because TSM does not have the capacity or production capacity for the high end chips needed to cover Apple's chip demand. As 22nm and 14nm INTEL chips hit the market ARM chips will soon no longer be able to compete with INTEL chips. In the short term TSM will produce the A7 while Apple products increasingly adopt the premium performance of INTEL's chips to stay competitive. Expect more hardware company defections from ARM chips to INTEL as INTEL slaughters the competition. I believe the timing on this will be Q1 2013.

Topic.Title: Barron's reporting Apple dropping Samsung

Message.Msg: There are 2 ways Intel is going to hurt TSMC and other foundries - directly and indirectly: (1) As Intel increases its process lead and competes aggressively in the mobile space, volumes at QCOM, NVDA, TI etc. may come down drastically - resulting in less mobile processor demand for TSMC. (2) From the foundry angle, Intel can sign up deals that may not be directly related to its x86 business. There are several rumors about Cisco signing up as a customer for Intel's foundry business. It will take only a few deals like this for Intel to further decimate the volumes and revenues of the "pure foundries", which will impact their capacity to invest in newer fabs and processes. We have seen some wins under (1) above. It will be great to see more announcements on Intel's big wins for its (2) foundry business.

Message.Title: Can we all agree that it is DEMAND that creates jobs?
Message.Msg: Can we all agree that it is DEMAND that creates job’s If both parties can agree that it is demand that creates jobs maybe we can move forward developing solutions to our country’s problems. When demand increases manufactures increase production to meet that demand (Econ 101). In most cases this results in additional employees being hired. These newly hired employees generally use the income that they receive to buy things that they need or want thereby increasing demand for those items. This cycle repeats itself again and again thereby creating more demand and more jobs until the cycle is finally broken. This cycle was broken in 2009 when the banking crisis developed, the stock market crashed, the housing market collapsed, and hundreds of thousands of individuals lost their jobs. So the question becomes what can our country do to increase demand. Here are a few suggestions for your consideration. 1.Reduce taxes on that segment of our population that will spend the increased income that is available to them. 2. Provide additional monetary stimulus to our economy by investing in our countries infrastructure. education, research and development and in new industries that will have a long term benefit to our society. 3. Provide tax incentives to companies bringing jobs back to the United States. If you have other suggestion lets hear them.

Message.Title: Ask Yourself These Questions??
Message.Msg: Are you getting your info on the interent from a mobile phone, tablet, laptop, or desktop? Are you holding off getting a new desktop or laptop because you need a faster PC? Are you holding off getting a new PC because you are dying for Windows 8? How do think the desktop/laptop business is doing in general? Hows Best Buy doing in this area? Now....what inning are we in as far as desktop and laptop computing? Hows things at AMD, IBM, HPQ, FB, etc? Ponder these things for a moment and really think about how much upside INTC has. Ignore the fact it used to be a $25 stock. But consider that this is a damaged stock and likely to be shunned for some time. There is no rush to go out and buy it....unless of course your criteria is "well it was $25 just a few weeks ago" That my friend is not an investment strategy. GLTA

Message.Title: Intel Reports Third-Quarter Revenue of $13.5 Billion
Message.Msg: Intel Reports Third-Quarter Revenue of $13.5 Billion 234.8 KB SANTA CLARA, Calif., Oct. 16, 2012 - Intel Corporation today reported quarterly revenue of $13.5 billion, operating income of $3.8 billion, net income of $3.0 billion and EPS of $0.58. The company generated approximately $5.1 billion in cash from operations, paid dividends of $1.1 billion and used $1.2 billion to repurchase stock. Our third-quarter results reflected a continuing tough economic environment," said Paul Otellini, Intel president and CEO. "The world of computing is in the midst of a period of breakthrough innovation and creativity. As we look to the fourth quarter, we're pleased with the continued progress in Ultrabooks and phones and excited about the range of Intel-based tablets coming to market." Q3 2012 Key Financial Information and Business Unit Trends (GAAP, unless otherwise stated) •PC Client Group revenue of $8.6 billion, flat sequentially and down 8 percent year-over-year •Data Center Group revenue of $2.7 billion, down 5 percent sequentially and up 6 percent year-over-year •Other Intel® architecture group revenue of $1.2 billion, up 6 percent sequentially and down 14 percent year-over-year •Gross margin of 63.3 percent, 1.3 percentage points above the midpoint of the company's updated expectation of 62 percent. •R&D plus MG&A spending $4.6 billion, unchanged. •Tax rate of 24 percent, below the company's expectation of approximately 28 percent. Business Outlook Intel's Business Outlook does not include the potential impact of any business combinations, asset acquisitions, divestitures or other investments that may be completed after Oct. 16. Q4 2012 (GAAP, unless otherwise stated) •Revenue: $13.6 billion, plus or minus $500 million. •Gross margin percentage: 57 percent and 58 percent Non-GAAP (excluding amortization of acquisition-related intangibles), both plus or minus a couple of percentage points. •R&D plus MG&A spending: approximately $4.5 billion. •Amortization of acquisition-related intangibles: approximately $75 million. •Impact of equity investments and interest and other: approximately $75 million. •Depreciation: approximately $1.6 billion. •Tax Rate: approximately 27 percent. •Full-year capital spending: $11.3 billion, plus or minus $300 million. intc

Topic.Title: Ask Yourself These Questions??

Message.Msg: Aviacionado.....I think you are the exception.....at least at this point in time. You need a faster pc to do what? What are you running that is going to be improved by a faster processor and a newer verson of windows? Tell me one thing Windows 8 will do for you that my Windows XP doesnt't do and really matters in the scheme of things? Like nyk20h said....PC's used to be replaced every 2 years and I will admit I was part of that cycle for the past 2 decades. But I see no software, except for perhaps games (both processor and vide intensive) that require anything new. I will offer this suggestion. If you have a second hard drive on your desktop put a new installation of Windows there and boot from it. I will predict you will see a significant improvement. The overhead of patches and security fixes packed onto an original windows install, will over time greatly degrade its performance. I think you will find that its not your processor or windows version that is slowing things down but rather a pasted, glued, and fragmented version of windows that has been slowing you down. Try it...I think you will be surprised.

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: Stocks have rallied the past couple of sessions on not-as-bad-as-feared earnings reports. This has allowed the bulls to regain short term momentum and some of the major indexes which had broken below their 50-day moving averages, such as the NASDAQ composite and Russell 2000, to reclaim that much watched technical line. However, since stocks topped out in September, the major indexes have carved out a short term downtrend after they made a lower-high-lower-low in October. The major indexes are now facing resistance from that short term downtrend. For the S&P 500, that resistance stands in the 1460-1465 area. Although earnings may be good enough to keep the downside limited, there may not be enough excitement to take the major indexes over resistance. have a nice evening

Message.Title: "Nobody wants Intel" says NYK2OH.....Not so, says Cisco
Message.Msg: Intel may be Cisco's foundry David Manners Friday 21 September 2012 01:00 Intel is talking to Cisco about becoming its foundry, says investment bank Piper Jaffray. According to the bankers, the deal could be worth $1bn a year to Intel. Cisco would be Intel's fourth announced foundry partner but by far the biggest. The other three announced partners, and there are said to be other unannounced partners, are Achronix, Tabula and Netronome. Netronome is a network processor company from Santa Clara, California Intel's home town, with whom Intel has been working for five years on development but onlt signed up for foundry services earlier this year. Under the agreement, Netronome also gets to use Intel's own EDA tools. Achronix and Tabula are FPGA companies. Achronix was the first, signing up for Intel foundry in 2010.

Message.Title: CEO Earnings Remarks
Message.Msg: In the coming months consumers will see tremendous form factor in industrial design innovation. There will be more than 140 Core based Ultrabooks, more than 40 of which will have touch. This will include more than a dozen convertibles that combine the productivity of the laptop with the convenience of a tablet. Many of the Ultrabook SKUs will hit the mainstream $699 price point with some Bridge SKUs well below even that number. Q4 will see more than 20 Atom based tablets from six or more leading OEMs using Clover Trail. Clover Trail is a brand new SoC that will enable tablets as thin as 8.5 millimeters and as light as 1.5 pounds. With three weeks of connected standby battery life and all of the compatibility that Windows users and Intel customers have come to expect. I am excited about these products and the capability they bring to consumers and the enterprise. We continue to make progress in handhelds with Motorola’s launch of the Razer I, the world’s only two gigahertz smart phone that delivers better battery life than similar competing devices. In general I see the computing market in a period of transition but also a period of breakthrough innovation and creativity. Intel has a history of navigating the industries transitions and emerging better and stronger. But the hardware and software road map expand the smallest portable devices to the most powerful data center servers and world leading silicon process technology, we are excited about the future and confident in our strategy and prospects in all the markets . [Wall Street was wrong. Instead of an $8 billion revenue miss there wasn't ANY revenue miss!!!]

Message.Title: CFO Earnings Remarks
Message.Msg: We significantly cut factory loading at the end of the quarter and we will maintain lower factory utilization rate throughout the fourth quarter we expect these factory adjustments to help bring down our total inventory levels by approximately a $1.2 billion additionally we are redirecting equipment in space to 14 nanometer from older generation technologies the result of this is a $1.2 billion decrease from our July forecast for capital spending with the mid point of our capital spending forecast for the year now at a $11.3 billion. Moving to gross margin third quarter gross margin of 63% was slightly better than the mid point of our revised guidance. We're taking aggressive tactical actions to reduce inventory levels and redirect space and equipment for (inaudible) but we're also seeing some positive trends in the market. In the client space, we're seeing innovative products coming to the market with Intel inside, ranging from ultrabooks to smartphones to tablets. In the datacenter, we expect to continue to benefit from the dole out of the cloud and substantial performance cost in (inaudible) that our enterprise customer get from our leadership products, underlying all of this, our manufacturing advantage that extending over the rest of the industry, as we start to (inaudible) well, our new micro architecture on 22-nanometer and begin to build out our 14 nanometer factory network. The combination of the tactical action we're taking coupled with new products and design wins across all segments in our manufacturing leadership will all benefit our business over the coming quarters.

Topic.Title: Yo Whobeli.. ask yourself these questions....

Message.Msg: " The yield is safe although you may disagree because you are a short" I wasn't saying that the yield wasn't safe....nor am I short. I think your confusing dividend and yield. The dividend is probably safe...but that doesn't mean the yield is. What I was trying to illustrate was that a dividend yield of 4.09% isn't some magic number that has in the past supported the share price of this or some other stocks. I used AT&T and its yield of 5% as an example. If the share price of INTC falls to $19, and I'm not saying it is or isn't, the dividend yield would then be 4.74%. Is there anything magical about that number? No. Does it make the stock more attractive? Sure. If the stock goes to $23, the dividend yield becomes 3.91%. Does it become less attractive? Probably a bit. At $25 the yield was 3.6%. At $22 the yield is 4.09% . The share price has fallen $3 since 9/6/2012, the dividend, when you get it, will only have protected you $0.225 cents, or 7% of the decline. Dividends are great when the market is moving higher as you get not only the share price apprecation but the dividend as well. In a decline, it does very little to buffer the pain except to take away some of the sting. Is it better than a stock that pays no dividend? Sure. Are high yielding stocks better in the long run that low or non yielding stocks. Sure again. But that does not mean that in the short run...there may be some share price pain as we have seen over the last several weeks. And often times the share price can challenge ones stamina in waiting around for 4% when the share price has fallen 20%. Just a thought

Message.Title: $450 Ivy Bridge Laptop vs $599 Microsoft Surface RT (With optional keyboard)
Message.Msg: The laptop: Asus, dual core Ivy Bridge processor, 15.6" display, 6GB RAM, 500GB storage, 64 bit Windows 7, compatibility with home and business networks and virtually every Windows app ever sold. Also has USB3.0 ports, Gigabit Ethernet adapter, Wi-Fi a/b/g/n, HDMI, webcam. Can boot from external USB devices useful to use security software such as the free CyberShield-OS for secure online banking and can use large external monitors. The Asus is $450 and comes with W8 upgrade. Microsoft Surface (ARM version) 10.8" display. Unknown RAM, Nvidia ARM processor, 32GB storage, Windows RT with limited functionality Office package. No Outlook and no legacy Windows applications. There may be a version of Angry Birds that runs on it. Touch screen. This is a closed box for accessing some email, light web surfing and entertainment. Tablet is $599 with keyboard. $600 is a huge price to pay for a closed box with very limited functionality and no legacy Windows support.
